metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: JavaScript Promises
"I Promise a Result!"
"Producing code" is code that can take some time
content.html: "Producing code" is code that can take some time

content.text: "Consuming code" is code that must wait for the result
content.html: "Consuming code" is code that must wait for the result

content.text: A Promise is an Object that links Producing code and Consuming code
content.html: A Promise is an Object that links Producing code and Consuming code

content.text: JavaScript Promise Object
A Promise contains both the producing code and calls to the consuming code:
content.html: A Promise contains both the producing code and calls to the consuming code:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // "Consuming Code" (Must wait for a fulfilled Promise)

syntax_highlighting.text: // "Consuming Code" (Must wait for a fulfilled Promise)

content.code_html:
let myPromise = new Promise(function(myResolve, myReject) {
// "Producing Code" (May take some time)
  myResolve(); // when successful
   myReject();  // when error
 });

// "Consuming Code" (Must wait for a fulfilled Promise)
 myPromise.then(
  function(value) { /* code if successful */ },
  function(error) { /* code if some error */ }
);

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // "Consuming Code" (Must wait for a fulfilled Promise)

content.text: When the producing code obtains the result, it should call one of the two callbacks:
content.html: When the producing code obtains the result, it should call one of the two callbacks:

content.text: Promise Object Properties
A JavaScript Promise object can be:
The Promise object supports two properties: state and result .
content.html: The Promise object supports two properties: state and result.

content.text: While a Promise object is "pending" (working), the result is undefined.
content.html: While a Promise object is "pending" (working), the result is undefined.

content.text: When a Promise object is "fulfilled", the result is a value.
content.html: When a Promise object is "fulfilled", the result is a value.

content.text: When a Promise object is "rejected", the result is an error object.
content.html: When a Promise object is "rejected", the result is an error object.

content.text: You cannot access the Promise properties state and result .
content.html: You cannot access the Promise properties state and result.

content.text: You must use a Promise method to handle promises.
content.html: You must use a Promise method to handle promises.

content.text: Promise How To
Here is how to use a Promise:
content.html: Here is how to use a Promise:

content.code_html:
myPromise.then(
  function(value) { /* code if successful */ },
  function(error) { /* code if some error */ }
);

content.text: Promise.then() takes two arguments, a callback for success and another for failure.
content.html: Promise.then() takes two arguments, a callback for success and another for failure.

content.text: Both are optional, so you can add a callback for success or failure only.
content.html: Both are optional, so you can add a callback for success or failure only.

syntaxHighlighting.text: // The producing code (this may take some time)

syntax_highlighting.text: // The producing code (this may take some time)

content.code_html:
function myDisplayer(some) {
  document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = some;
}

let myPromise = new Promise(function(myResolve, myReject) {
  let x = 0;

// The producing code (this may take some time)

  if (x == 0) {
    myResolve("OK");
  } else {
    myReject("Error");
  }
});

myPromise.then(
  function(value) {myDisplayer(value);},
  function(error) {myDisplayer(error);}
);

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // The producing code (this may take some time)

content.text: JavaScript Promise Examples
To demonstrate the use of promises, we will use the callback examples from the previous chapter:
content.html: To demonstrate the use of promises, we will use the callback examples from the previous chapter:

content.text: Waiting for a Timeout

content.code_html:
setTimeout(function() { myFunction("I love You !!!"); }, 3000);

function myFunction(value) {
  document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = value;
}

let myPromise = new Promise(function(myResolve, myReject) {
  setTimeout(function() { myResolve("I love You !!"); }, 3000);
});

myPromise.then(function(value) {
  document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = value;
});

content.text: Waiting for a file

content.code_html:
function getFile(myCallback) {
  let req = new XMLHttpRequest();
  req.open('GET', "mycar.html");
  req.onload = function() {
    if (req.status == 200) {
      myCallback(req.responseText);
    } else {
      myCallback("Error: " + req.status);
    }
  }
  req.send();
}

getFile(myDisplayer);

let myPromise = new Promise(function(myResolve, myReject) {
  let req = new XMLHttpRequest();
  req.open('GET', "mycar.html");
  req.onload = function() {
    if (req.status == 200) {
      myResolve(req.response);
    } else {
      myReject("File not Found");
    }
  };
  req.send();
});

myPromise.then(
  function(value) {myDisplayer(value);},
  function(error) {myDisplayer(error);}
);

content.text: Browser Support
ECMAScript 2015, also known as ES6, introduced the JavaScript Promise object.
content.html: ECMAScript 2015, also known as ES6, introduced the JavaScript Promise object.

content.text: The following table defines the first browser version with full support for Promise objects:
content.html: The following table defines the first browser version with full support for Promise objects:

content.code_html:
Chrome 33 Edge 12 Firefox 29 Safari 7.1 Opera 20
Feb, 2014 Jul, 2015 Apr, 2014 Sep, 2014 Mar, 2014
